Week 39: Small escapes

1 Oct 2023
  • First of all: not a great week. I continue to struggle to notice when I feel stresed or overwhelmed, and it never fails to result in my body giving me a clear sign. On Monday evening, in the midst of a busy work month, my body said ‚ÄúSIT. DOWN.‚Äù I needed undtil well into the weekend to feel myself again.
  • One of the signs my body knows to give it a very mild version of conversion disorder: I lose the ability to listen to a conversation while I walk without feeling very dizzy. Isn‚Äôt the body a beautiful, very annoying, but magnificent thing?
  • I start back up at work on Thursday, working the mornings until the weekend. It‚Äôs good to acknowledge things aren‚Äôt great., It brings clarity and rest.
  • On Friday evening I attend the first edition of a new local film club I joined. It confirms what I already know: I love the horror genre, and I love discussing cinema with people who didn‚Äôt finish film school Anja I‚Äôm looking at you.
  • Ever since we visited Hija de Sanchez in Copenhagen Anja and I have gotten really into Mexican food. By now, I‚Äôm so well-versed in the art of a simple-but-sublime taco, that I whip up a delicious meal. Who knew tacos required so little filling?
  • On Saturday, I visit Micropia, a zoo-adjacent museum about microbes. I expect to be queasy throughout the entire visit, terrified by the unfortunate-looking mini animals that live in and on every part of my body. Instead, I‚Äôm amazed by the beauty of nature. During the mini class I ask a question about algae: if their bodies move towards light and they‚Äôre under a microscope for a while, where light comes from all sides, what happens to their health? The laboratory assistant tells me the museum swaps petri dishes regularly so that the algea don‚Äôt die. What happens before death, though, I wonder.
  • On Sunday, Chenelva comes over for afternoon drinks. She‚Äôs one of those rare people: an instant connection and plenty of common ground to grow out friendship on. We marvel at how little we know about queer BIPOC Amsterdam.
  • We‚Äôve completed the first season of the Dutch reality show ‚ÄúB&B vol liefde‚Äù, in which B&B owners invite four dates into their home. Hate-watching reality television with Anja is one of my favorite pastimes.

As per my privacy policy, I won't know you've been here unless you tell me. Let me know what you think about this either via email, Mastodon or webmention. I would love to hear from you!

Zinzy Waleson Geene is an Afropean, queer researcher and designer from Amsterdam (NL).
